awd_abstract_narration:
This project at the Rock Creek campus of Portland Community College (PCC) in Oregon, entitled Mentoring in Manufacturing Technology (MeMT), is designed to address the important national issue of increasing educational opportunities for low-income, academically talented science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) students by providing scholarships and strong curricular and co-curricular support. The project will focus on recruitment and retention strategies that have proven successful in increasing the number of females and underrepresented minorities in STEM careers and will add to the knowledge base of what works in recruitment and retention strategies, for whom, and in what circumstances. In addition, the project will research the extent to which embedding mathematical strategies into targeted gateway courses enables students to better understand the engineering mathematics in later engineering technology courses and programs and the effectiveness of a formal mentoring program upon retention of scholars to graduation. The project has two connecting strategies for broadening impact: 1) to evaluate the effectiveness of activities that lower barriers to participation for females and other underrepresented students in STEM fields, and 2) to implement and sustain evidence-based practices that have an impact on recruitment, retention and degree completion of underrepresented groups in STEM fields and to share the practices that had the greatest impact and would benefit other institutions. 

A total of 80 one-year scholarships will be awarded to students enrolled in Microelectronics Technology, Solar Voltaic Manufacturing Technology, and Automated Manufacturing Technology, and eight one-year scholarships for scholars transferring to Oregon Institute of Technology seeking a baccalaureate degree in Electronics Engineering Technology, Electrical Engineering, and Manufacturing Engineering Technology. The overall objectives of the MeMT program are to 1) increase the percentage of females enrolled in targeted engineering technology programs from 18% to 25% over five years; 2) increase the percentage of minorities enrolled in targeted engineering technology programs from 25% to 35% over five years; 3) retain 90% of scholars to completion of an associate degree; 4) ensure that 90% of graduating scholars will be employed in a position related to their degree/major or enrolled at Oregon Institute of Technology; and 5) increase the retention rate of students in targeted entry-level courses. The MeMT project will implement and test a student mentoring program based on scholar, faculty and alumni/industry participation that is being adapted from materials developed by the University of Maryland, Baltimore County Center for their Women in Technology program along with the ENGAGE Faculty-Student Interactions.  A STEM Camp and two STEM workshops each year will be offered and will be open to high school seniors, with marketing and recruitment focusing on minorities and women. A cohort-building structure will be put into place where scholars will be scheduled within the same classes where possible.  One-on-one intrusive academic advising will be required for scholars, as will small-group and individual tutoring for those who need additional assistance. NSF-funded initiatives that include the Institute for Women in Trades, Technology, and Science (IWITTS) and ENGAGE Engineering will be adapted to assist in recruiting and retaining females and underrepresented minorities into the three targeted programs. Faculty members will receive training for incorporating these strategies into activities and curriculum. Everyday Examples in Engineering, Spatial Visualization Skills, and concept-based formulas, graphs, and other representations will be incorporated into classes that prepare students to solve mathematics problems in gateway engineering courses.

por.por_cntn:
In 2016, the Mentoring in Manufacturing Technology (MeMT) project team from Portland Community College (PCC) started the implementation of the MeMT Program, its processes, and its procedures.

The major goal of the (MeMT) project was to increase the recruitment, retention, student success, and graduation rates (including student transfer) of low-income, academically-talented students with demonstrated financial need who are pursuing an Associate of Applied Science (AAS) degree in Microelectronics Technology, Solar Manufacturing Technology (SOL) or Automated Manufacturing Technology (AUT) programs at PCC Rock Creek. The proposal?s intention was to award STEM scholarships to 40 students who will graduate and to 6 transfer students to 4-year universities, in STEM programs. 

During the six-year project, the project team recruited 72 scholars, all representatives of underserved populations in the community.  Out of the total of 72, 60 have graduated and found full-time employment as cleanroom technicians with the local semiconductor industry.  This makes the graduate-employment rate 100%.

Six scholars have transferred to Portland State University (PSU) into various Engineering Bachelor programs, 3 are still active MT students, expected to graduate in 2023 and 3 quit the program before graduation, for employment. Based on these numbers, we may quantify the scholar success rate as being 95.8% (69 out of 72).

The overall MT student enrollment linearly increased during the first 4 years of the project. That trend was reversed in 2020 during the pandemic but currently is bouncing back. The same trajectory was noticed in the percentage of women enrolled in the MT, which reached a peak of 29% just before the pandemic started, and was followed by a decrease at the end of 2020.

The MeMT project also intended to adapt, implement, and study models, effective evidence-based practices, and strategies that contribute to understanding how these practices affect recruitment, retention, student success, academic/career pathways, and/or degree attainment in STEM of low-income, academically-talented students with demonstrated financial need.

During the six-year project, the project team organized and offered 10 STEM camps. These three-day-long STEM events were the main recruiting mechanism for scholars who demonstrated to be talented and had serious financial needs. Once enrolled in the academic MT program, these scholars, representatives of underserved populations in the community, were mentored by MT faculty and industry professionals, consistently guided and supported in their academic endeavors. Many were placed in internships at local semiconductor companies like Intel, Microchip, Qorvo, Lam Research, ADI-Maxim Integrated. Following graduation with the Associate of Applied Science Degree in MT, 100% found full-time employment with the local semiconductor industries, the majority being hired by Intel in Hillsboro.

During the six-year project, in the process of recruiting, mentoring, and guiding the STEM scholars through their challenges and successes, the project team developed a wonderful model for technician education, a model that combines a strong technical program with real-work experience through internships, and financial assistance through scholarships.

Over the past 6 years, the MeMT S-STEM project had a positive contribution to workforce development in the state of OR. As a result, in 2022, the PCC-MT program was included on the list of Community Projects recommended for government funding.

The Community Project Funding was passed as part of the Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2023 to fund the government for the next year. The package includes a generous grant for Portland Community College to fund semiconductor and advanced manufacturing workforce training and support services. This will be a very beneficial continuation of the MeMT project, allowing PCC and Microelectronics Technology to continue playing a positive role in the semiconductor industry workforce development.
